sub_topic: Show that every group of order p^2, where p is a prime, is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of two cyclic groups of order p.
message_1: Prove that every group of order 49 is either cyclic or isomorphic to the direct product of two cyclic groups of order 7.
message_2:
Let G be a group of order 49. Since 49 = 7^2, by the Sylow Theorems, there exists a Sylow 7-subgroup of G, say H. The number of Sylow 7-subgroups of G is equal to 1 mod 7 and divides 49, so there are either 1 or 7 Sylow 7-subgroups. 

Case 1: There is only one Sylow 7-subgroup.
In this case, H is the unique Sylow 7-subgroup, and thus it is normal in G. Since |H| = 7, H is a cyclic group generated by some element a with order 7. Now, G/H is a group of order 7, so it is also cyclic, generated by some coset bH with order 7. Then G is generated by a and b, and since H is normal in G, we have that G is isomorphic to the direct product of H and G/H, both of which are cyclic groups of order 7. Thus, G is isomorphic to the direct product of two cyclic groups of order 7.

Case 2: There are 7 Sylow 7-subgroups.
Let H and K be two distinct Sylow 7-subgroups of G. Since |H| = |K| = 7, both H and K are cyclic, generated by elements a and b, respectively, with order 7. The intersection of H and K is trivial, as their intersection would be a subgroup of both H and K, and since H and K are distinct and have prime order, their intersection must be the identity element. Thus, |HK| = |H||K|/|H ∩ K| = 7 * 7 / 1 = 49. Since |G| = 49, we have that G = HK. 

Now, we show that G is abelian. Let h ∈ H and k ∈ K. Since H and K are distinct Sylow 7-subgroups, hk ≠ kh implies that hk and kh are in different Sylow 7-subgroups. However, both hk and kh are in HK = G, and since there are only 7 Sylow 7-subgroups, one of them must be in H or K. Without loss of generality, assume hk ∈ H. Then kh = (hk)^(-1) ∈ H as well, which contradicts our assumption that hk ≠ kh. Therefore, hk = kh for all h ∈ H and k ∈ K, and G is abelian.

Since G is abelian and generated by a and b, both of order 7, G is isomorphic to the direct product of the cyclic groups generated by a and b, which are both of order 7. Thus, G is isomorphic to the direct product of two cyclic groups of order 7.

In conclusion, every group of order 49 is either cyclic (in the case where there is only one Sylow 7-subgroup) or isomorphic to the direct product of two cyclic groups of order 7 (in the case where there are 7 Sylow 7-subgroups).
